awd_abstract_narration:
Many industrially important chemical production processes require significant energy input to drive the chemical reactions. When this power is provided by heating the chemical reactants, undesired side reactions can take place reducing the process yield and potentially posing a safety risk. While much more controlled power inputs exist, sources such as lasers have fixed wavelengths and so are limited to use in only a handful of reactions. In this work, a new approach is proposed to use quantum mechanical principles to design chemical reactors that can redirect random chemical reactant molecular motions to promote a specific chemical reaction. Much like a catalyst, this would result in greater chemical reactor efficiency. The unique combination of chemistry and quantum mechanics proposed would lead to a new approach for chemical synthesis by design. This project will leverage a close collaboration between the University of Chicago and Argonne National Laboratory for the successful implementation of this multidisciplinary study. This research will also contribute to the education and mentoring of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers involved through their training and research during the project. Outreach programs developed during this project will foster the integration of research and teaching, as well as the participation of underrepresented groups.


Electronic ground state reactions rely on the excitation of specific vibrational motions along the reaction coordinates. However, selective excitation of one specific vibrational mode of a chemical bond while leaving the others intact is challenging. The principle intellectual merit of the proposed work is to address this long-standing challenge faced by the chemical synthesis community and develop a reaction control mechanism that not only allows bond-selective excitation of chemical reactions, but also the modulation of reaction potential energy surfaces. The quantum coherence approach developed here would enable the tuning of a particular reaction channel’s potential barrier for its reaction rate acceleration or deceleration. During the first stage of the project, we will focus on understanding the influence of the quantum coherence effects on several key reaction parameters, including the reaction rate, selectivity, and yield. In the second stage, we aim to optimize the reaction control mechanism and adapt it to potential scale-up applications. Two important chemical reactions will be studied in this work and will serve as representatives of a wide range of potential applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

In this project, our goal was to gain fundamental understanding of the influences of vibrational strong coupling on ground-state chemical reactions, and explore the potential of using this mechanism for reaction control. Within this award, we addressed several key questions that would contribute to the advance of this field. We list the key outcomes of this project below.

Influences of polaritonic bright and dark states on chemical reactivity. We used hydrolysis reactions as examples, in which the vibrational modes of reactants were strongly coupled to Fabry-Pérot cavity modes. We discovered that the reaction rates were closely related to the strong coupling conditions, which were manifested as Rabi splitting and mode detuning. In particular, at reduced Rabi splitting and/or increased mode detuning, a large acceleration in the reaction rate was observed, while the reaction rates decreased with increasing Rabi splitting and/or reduced mode detuning. Since the strong coupling conditions reflected the contributions of polaritonic bright and dark states in the overall system, we were able to derive that in the investigated reactions, resonant effects caused by the polaritonic bright states and thermalization effect related to the dark states collectively determine the overall reactivity. These findings suggest that by adjusting the strong coupling conditions and the related contributions of polaritonic bright and dark states, it is feasible to control the reactivity of ground-state chemical reactions via vibrational strong coupling. We applied this mechanism to several other reactions for reactivity modulation.

Photonic resonators for vibrational strong coupling. We designed, simulated, and fabricated new types of photonic structures that could concentrate electromagnetic fields to sub-wavelength limits. These resonators have the potential to serve as infrared light concentrators that can couple to vibrational modes.

Broader Impacts:

The fundamental knowledge obtained in this project could provide new insights into polariton chemistry and vibrational strong coupling. Through outreach programs, this project also provided interdisciplinary training opportunities to our next-generation workforce. Research results from this project were disseminated through peer-reviewed journals, conferences, divisional seminars, and science fairs.
